TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in ORG .

CARDINAL . NORP In accordance with an agreement on the division of their mutual property with her former husband , approved by a court decision on CARDINAL DATE , the applicant was entitled to a number of shares in CARDINAL companies owned by the husband .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought a civil action , requesting that the value of the shares in CARDINAL of the companies be awarded to her .

CARDINAL . On DATE , during the hearing of the applicant ’s case , ORG discovered some evidence of crime , allegedly committed by the director and the chief accountant of those companies . In particular , they were suspected of embezzlement and fraud ( ORG CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW as then in force ) . The court considered that , in these circumstances :
“ it was not possible to assess the value of [ the applicant ’s ] claims ; therefore , her civil action should be referred for an examination in the framework of the criminal proceedings . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was afforded the status of a victim in those proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE she was granted the status of a civil claimant in the criminal proceedings .
She was further granted the status of a civil claimant on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE several other criminal procedures against the director were joined in CARDINAL set of proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE an expert examination was ordered . It was completed on DATE .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicant requested the institution of further criminal proceedings against the director and other employees of the companies , alleging that they had falsified certificates as to the number and value of the shares which had belonged to her former husband . On DATE the prosecutors dismissed her request .

CARDINAL . On DATE the bill of indictment against the director of the companies and CARDINAL other co - accused was approved . The original charges of embezzlement and fraud were supplemented with accusations of forgery and negligent accountancy ( respectively , Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW as then in force ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the accused were committed for trial .
CARDINAL . Hearings scheduled for DATE and CARDINAL DATE were adjourned at the request of the defendants .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court ordered a further expert examination . It was completed on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the trial was adjourned due to the illness of the defendants .

CARDINAL . Hearings scheduled for DATE , DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE and DATE were partially adjourned because certain witnesses failed to appear before the court . The court questioned those witnesses present and ordered the police to bring the remaining witnesses to the next hearing .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was adjourned due to the illness of the judge .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was again adjourned due to the failure of certain witnesses to appear .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the hearing was further adjourned since CARDINAL of the defendants had failed to appear due to illness .
CARDINAL . On DATE another expert examination was ordered at the request of the prosecution .
CARDINAL . In a letter to the prosecution of DATE , ORG noted that the proceedings had lasted an unduly long time due to deficiencies in the pre - trial investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG decided to exclude the applicant from the list of civil claimants . The applicant unsuccessfully challenged the decision , the courts ruling that domestic law did not provide her with a right of appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG convicted the defendants .
CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE , ORG informed the applicant that she could appeal against the judgment of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested renewal of the time - limit to lodge an appeal against her exclusion from the list of civil claimants .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG granted her request . It was noted that the courts had erred in deciding that the domestic law had precluded the applicant from appealing .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal whereby she challenged the decision of CARDINAL DATE and the judgment of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG refused to admit the applicant ’s appeal . The court noted that the applicant was not a participant in the trial , and therefore was not entitled to appeal against the judgment DATE . Moreover , the court found that the applicant had failed to comply with the time - limit for appeal without good reason .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant challenged that decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG granted her appeal . The court renewed the time - limit for appeal against the judgment of DATE . It was noted , inter alia , that the courts had unduly restricted the applicant ’s rights by refusing to accept her appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG quashed the decision of DATE whereby the applicant had been deprived of the status of civil claimant . It was noted that the impugned decision had breached the applicant ’s rights . The judgment of CARDINAL DATE was also quashed , and the case was remitted for a fresh examination .
CARDINAL . A hearing scheduled for DATE was adjourned as CARDINAL of the defendants , certain witnesses and defence counsel had failed to appear .
CARDINAL . On DATE the trial hearing was further adjourned due to the failure to summon CARDINAL of the defendants .

CARDINAL . Following the applicant ’s hierarchical complaint about the actions of ORG , an inquiry was conducted by ORG . In a letter of DATE , the latter informed the applicant that ORG had not undertaken all the necessary measures to ensure a speedy trial .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG convicted the defendants of forgery and negligent bookkeeping , and acquitted them of the original charges of embezzlement and fraud .

CARDINAL . By the same judgment , the trial court decided to leave the applicant ’s civil claims “ without examination ” . The court noted that the defendants had neither been accused of nor tried for offences which could have caused damage to the applicant ’s interests as a shareholder . It further reasoned that , as a shareholder , the applicant had no entitlement to any part of the property of a joint - stock company . Only if the company had been liquidated could she claim a part of its property , together with other shareholders . It noted that the applicant had a possibility to pursue her claims by way of a separate civil action . The court concluded that “ the applicant should not be deemed a victim or civil claimant in this case ” .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , complaining that she had incurred significant pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage , particularly as the examination of the case had taken DATE . She reiterated that the criminal case had been instituted on the basis of her civil action , and that she had been granted the status of victim and civil claimant .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . It noted :

“ The victim , ORG , took part in the examination of the case throughout the proceedings ; she was entitled [ inter alia ] to submit a civil claim and the evidence in order to substantiate it . However ... the submission of a civil claim does not presuppose the obligation on the part of the court to satisfy it . ... The first - instance court has reasonably established that the victim ’s right to part of the company ’s property would only arise in accordance with company law , and has correctly noted that [ the applicant ] could defend her property rights in accordance with the civil procedure . ...

When adopting the ... judgment , the court must also decide on the civil claim . Civil claims can only be granted if [ the defendants are convicted ] , and it is established that the civil claimant had suffered pecuniary damage due to the criminal acts in question ; finally , there must be a causal link between the criminal actions and the damage incurred . ...
The defendants were not tried for any offence which could have caused damage to [ the applicant ] . ...
As to [ the applicant ’s ] property rights , they are not the object of this criminal case . It is the object of civil law and has only to be decided in accordance with the civil proceedings . ”

CARDINAL . The court further noted that the examination of the case had been unjustifiably long , in breach of LAW , LAW and LAW . The court concluded however that , despite the acknowledgement of the breach , “ it was not possible to remedy this flaw at the current stage of the proceedings ” . On DATE , the judgment of DATE entered into force .

CARDINAL . The applicant lodged a cassation appeal , complaining , inter alia , that the courts had failed to bring additional charges of forgery against the defendants , which would have allowed their conviction and the satisfaction of her civil claims . She also alleged that the length of the proceedings had been excessive .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s cassation appeal . ORG established that the prosecution had rightly refused to bring additional charges against the defendants , as they had found no evidence of the crimes alleged by the applicant .

CARDINAL . With respect to the applicant ’s civil claims , ORG noted that her entitlement to a certain number of shares had not been questioned . It also found that , in the share certificates issued by the defendants , the number and value of shares belonging to the applicant had been wrongly calculated and did not correspond to the data appearing in the company ’s statute . ORG concluded , however , that this error did not restrict the applicant ’s rights as a shareholder ; nor did it cause her any pecuniary or non - pecuniary damage . ORG further concluded that , in such circumstances , there had been no basis to grant the applicant the status of a civil claimant .

CARDINAL . Finally , ORG endorsed the findings of the appellate court as to the length of the proceedings . It emphasised , however , that it was not reasonable to consider that the excessive length was an “ essential violation ” of LAW since , in such a case , the decisions of the lower courts would have to be quashed , and this would have only further prolonged the examination of the case .
CARDINAL . The applicant did not bring a new civil action .
“ The person whose constitutional rights or freedoms are violated shall have the right to apply to court . ”
CARDINAL . The ruling of ORG of DATE stipulates :

“ ... by virtue of the LAW , a person has the right to claim compensation for damage caused by the unlawful actions of ORG institutions and agents , even if such compensation is not foreseen by law ; the courts adjudicating such cases ... have the power to award appropriate compensation by directly applying the principles of the LAW ... as well as the general principles of law , while being guided inter alia by the principle of reasonableness , etc ” .
